title: 'Don't come back': Opportunistic employee goes home early when a scheduled fire drill makes management second-guess their instructional wording
description: Managerial ultimatums are never a good idea. Often taken out of context or as a display of power, a workplace ultimatum can get lost in translation, leading to a trip down the hall to the HR office or a completely misunderstood instruction. And when it comes to a fire drill in the workplace, management can't afford to make mistakes that could cost them their precious data, because without that 200% success rate, who are the shareholders going to congratulate?
author: Jesse Kessenheimer

html:
This employee was full of snarky energy and decided to use their manager's unclear ultimatum to their advantage. Understanding that they had a workplace fire drill coming up, they listened carefully—a little too carefully—the the instructions over the P.A. system. “If you leave the property during the drill, don't bother coming back."

Well, well, well, you got it, boss! Perhaps it was the extra dash of sass in their morning cold brew or the audacity of testing the limits, but this employee decided to take this ultimatum and turn it into a half-day at the office!
